heading: net stocks hit accelerator
subheading: wall street turns multimedia as aol breaks into television and yahoo discovers radio. meantime, thestreet.com goes public -- a day trader's dream. by david lazarus.
author: david lazarus
text: internet stocks rode point for wall street on tuesday as america online revealed an ambitious plan to launch an interactive tv service. enthusiasm also was fueled by the trading debut of thestreet.com, which, to no one's surprise, went nuclear. blue-chip shares did mostly well, but retreated from their earlier highs. the dow jones industrial average rose 18.90 points to close at 11026.15, with wal-mart stores (wmt) accounting for much of the advance. the world's biggest retailer climbed us$1.81 to $47 after posting quarterly earnings of 25 cents a diluted share, topping estimates by 3 cents.tech stocks took their cue from the dot-com crowd, which was basking in aol's looming leap from the pc to the boob tube. the wired index gained 13.89 to 659.12, and the nasdaq composite index was 40.27 higher at 2566.66. the s&p 500 was up 15.31 at 1355.61.investors had additional reason to smile. the us labor department reported that employment costs in the first quarter rose at a mere 0.3 percent annual rate, which was less than economists had expected and suggests that inflation remains nowhere to be seen. productivity in the period slowed just a tick.with the economy humming along just fine, traders amused themselves by tossing shares of aol (aol) back and forth. the company's shares jumped $11.19 to $139.50 after it inked pacts with directv, hughes network services, network computer inc., and royal philips electronics to funnel net content into the living room. morgan stanley dean witter scored an assist by upgrading aol's stock to "strong buy" from "outperform."by coincidence -- or not? -- yahoo (yhoo) grabbed some of the spotlight by announcing its entry into the online radio field. the company's shares rose 12 percent to $174 as crossing over into other media became the dominant theme for leading internet lights."the portals have to diversify," said mike wallace, an analyst with warburg dillon read. "everyone's going there. the only one that's standing still is lycos."looks that way. lycos (lcos) fell $7 to $98.25 as investors awaited news as to whether usa networks is dropping its plans to buy the portal. after the closing bell, the news broke on cnbc: all is kaput.in the fun guessing game as to who now will make a play for lycos, wallace likes time warner, which recently chucked its pathfinder gateway and could be in the market for a used portal. "the issue is how they would structure a deal and pay for it," he said. (legal fine print: lycos is in the process of acquiring wired news.)with net stocks once again on fire, thestreet.com (tscm) couldn't have picked a better day to go public. the online financial news service -- one of the most eagerly anticipated ipos in months -- saw its stock more than triple to $60 after arriving with 5.5 million shares starting at $19 each. the company had a loss of more than $16 million last year.but investors can be forgiven for ignoring thestreet's soggy bottom line. the company's backers include the likes of the new york times co. and rupert murdoch's news corp., and observers rightly note that financial news is one of the hotter commodities on the web, right up there with naughty pictures.rob martin, an analyst with friedman, billings, ramsey, said thestreet's prospects for profitability are greatly enhanced by the fact that it takes in revenue from subscriptions as well as advertising. "it's the first hybrid model that's seen some success," he said.now get this: hitsgalore.com (hitt), a business-oriented search service that prides itself on the "moral" value of its content, got pounded as bloomberg news reported that its founder, dorian reed, hadn't disclosed that he was accused of cheating customers at a previous job as a telemarketer. hitsgalore's stock tumbled 53 percent to $9.38.so much for the moral high ground.in tech, all eyes were on cisco systems (csco), which rose $2.63 to $111.88. the company was slated to report its quarterly earnings after the closing bell, and income of 37 cents a share was expected. a more than 30 percent hike in revenue also was anticipated. if cisco outdoes either of these numbers, investors will feel a whole lot better about hardware makers as we near the second half of the year.dell computer (dell) advanced 38 cents to $42.63 as bt alex. brown upgraded the company's stock to "buy" from "market perform." international business machines (ibm) gained $2.50 to $221.13, and intel (intc) was up $1.69 at $62.31.can you say "bundle"? qwest communications international (qwst) climbed $1.25 to $92.75 after joining with hewlett-packard and sap america to hawk net-based services to businesses. qwest will provide the network, hp the hardware and support, and sap the software. a pretty snazzy combo.immunex (imnx) led biotech firms back into the promised land, soaring 33 percent to $142.31 on word that its arthritis drug enbrel had come through tests with flying colors. american home products (ahp), which owns a majority stake in immunex, was up $2.88 at $62.63.lastly, sony (sne) closed unchanged at $93 following news that the company will begin selling a robot dog named aibo. the pint-size pooch has sensors in its paws and a camera to keep it from bumping into the furniture. aibo can sit and beg and, when pleased, will wag its tail.all for just $2,500. or for about $2,480 less, dog lovers can head down to the local spca and give a home to a proper puppy, which won't short out in the rain and won't require the user to hit ctrl-alt-delete every 45 minutes.
